Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Oral Choline Supplementation for Pain Management Post-Gynaecological Surgery

Background: Activation of nicotinic receptors with nicotine reduces post-surgical pain. Choline, a selective agonist at Î±7-type nicotinic receptors, is anti-nociceptive in animal studies without addictive properties. This study evaluates oral choline supplementation with lecithin for pain management after gynaecological surgery.

Methods: In a double-blind, randomised controlled trial, 60 women undergoing open gynaecological surgery were randomly assigned to receive 20 g of lecithin or placebo. The primary outcome was pain report at rest and with movement, measured postoperatively. Plasma choline concentration and tumour necrosis factor (TNF) were secondary outcomes. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Results: Sixty participants were randomised: 30 to the intervention and 30 to the control group. A small but statistically significant increase in plasma choline was observed in the intervention group. However, there was no significant difference in pain reports between groups. Plasma TNF levels were not reduced. No adverse effects were reported in either group.

Interpretation: Oral lecithin supplementation resulted in slow absorption and a small increase in plasma choline, insufficient to reduce TNF or pain. The absence of an anti-inflammatory effect likely contributed to the lack of efficacy in pain reduction.
